text:
CELLS

Cell is the biological unit of life. There are two forms of cells, prokaryotes and eukaryotes. Cells that lack a well-organized nucleus are called prokaryotic cells and we define these cells as cells that do not have membrane-bound organelles. Examples are Bacteria and cyano-bacteria. 

Types of Cell

On the basis of the organisation of nucleus, cells can be divided into two types – prokaryotic cell and eukaryotic cell.

a) Prokaryotic cell:

A prokaryotic cell does not contain any true nucleus. This is why it is called a cell with a primitive type of nucleus. The term nucleotide fits nice in this case. Nuclear materials in a prokaryotic cell are not surrounded by any nuclear membrane. They are dispersed in its cytoplasm. Though the cell organelles such as mitochondria, plastids, endoplasmic reticule etc. are not found in a prokaryotic cell, ribosomes are present in it. Only the unwrapped DNA constitutes the chromosomal structure of a prokaryotic cell. For example, blue green algae and bacteria are constituted of this type of cell.

 

b) Eukaryotic cell:

In this type of cell, nucleus is well structured that means nuclear materials are well organised and surrounded by a nuclear membrane. Chromosomes are organised with DNA, histone protein and other components. From algae to higher flowering plants and from Amoeba to advanced animals, the basic structural and functional component is eukaryotic type of cell. Along with ribosome, other cell organelles are present in the cell.

 

On the basis of function, there are two other types of cells: somatic cell and gametic cell.

i) Somatic cell: This type of cell takes part in the organisation of the body of an organism. The cell divides through the process of binary fission and mitotic division. Organisms grow in this way. Moreover, cells take part in the organisation of different organs and organ systems.

ii) Gametic cell – Gametic cells are produced in the organisms in which sexual reproduction and alternation of generations occur. Primordial germ cells divide through meiotic division and produce gametic cells. In a gametic cell, number of chromosomes becomes half than that of its somatic type. A new living body is commenced after the fusion of male and female gametes. Half-life fuses with another half-life to produce a full life. Zygote is the first cell produced after the union of male and female gametic cells. Zygote undergoes repeated mitotic division to organise a body of an organism.

We also have the plant cell and the animal cells.

Eukaryotes are organisms whose cells have a nucleus enclosed within membranes, unlike prokaryotes, which have no membrane-bound organelles. Examples are the plant and animal cells.

UNN PUTME Example

Cells without an organized nucleus are called

A. Heterokaryote B. Eukaryote C. Prokaryote D. Synkaryote

(C. Cells that lack a well-organized nucleus are called prokaryotic cells and we define these cells as cells that do not have membrane-bound organelles. Examples are Bacteria and cyano-bacteria, 2010/2011, no 2)

More examples are given at the end of the chapter

Plant contains cellulose cell wall which the animal cell lacks. The cell wall makes the plant cell rigid. The main structural differences between plant and animal cells lie in a few additional structures found in plant cells. These structures include: chloroplasts, the cell wall, and vacuoles.

Chloroplasts are green because they contain the pigment chlorophyll, which is vital for photosynthesis. Chlorophyll occurs in several distinct forms. Chlorophylls a and b are the major pigments found in higher plants and green algae.

Food is stored in the form of glycogen in animals whereas, in the form of starch in plants.

Starch is accumulated in the chloroplasts of most species after photosynthesis. Starch is not the first product of photosynthesis. It is the product of a secondary reaction called starch synthesis. It is formed by the condensation of sugar.

Spongy tissue is a type of tissue found both in plants and animals. In plants, it is part of the mesophyll, where it forms a layer next to the palisade cells in the leaf. The spongy mesophyll's function is to allow for the interchange of gases (CO2) that are needed for photosynthesis.

Plant stores their waste product in their cell vacuoles and cell walls of leaves.

Components of A Cell

a) Cell wall: Cell wall is the unique and outstanding feature of a plant cell. It is composed of inert materials. Cellulose, hemicelluloses, lignin, pectin, suberin are the chemical components of a plant cell wall. But bacterial cell wall is composed of protein and lipid. Cell wall protects a cell from all external injuries. It gives a cell its rigidity. Cell wall protects and maintain the shape and size of a cell. For exchanging materials with the adjacent cell, plasmodesmata are formed in a cell wall.

Cell wall controls the movement of water and minerals. There is no cell wall around an

animal cell.

b) Plasma lemma: The double layered membrane around the protoplasm of a cell is called cell membrane or plasmalemma.

 

c) Cytoplasmic organelles: The semi-transparent, jel-like, semisolid substance in a cell is called protoplasm. All the contents surrounded by the cell membrane is protoplasm. They have different functions. Now, let us move on to the functions of organelles.

1. Mitochondria

Mitochondria are known as the powerhouses of the cell. They are organelles that act like a digestive system which takes in nutrients, breaks them down, and creates energy rich molecules for the cell. The biochemical processes of the cell are known as cellular respiration. It contains chemicals that break up complex compounds in the cells into simpler compounds. Mitochondrion contain DNA and changes shape. It is therefore not exactly an organelle like others. Mitochondria are membrane-bound cell organelles (mitochondrion, singular) that generate most of the chemical energy needed to power the cell's biochemical reactions. Chemical energy produced by the mitochondria is stored in a small molecule called adenosine triphosphate (ATP).

2. Plastids

Plastids are membrane-bound organelles with their own DNA. Examples are chloroplasts, chromoplasts and leucoplast. Chloroplasts contain the green pigment chlorophyll and carry out photosynthesis. Chromoplasts make and store other pigments. They give flower petals their bright colors. Leucoplasts are non-pigmented in contrast to other plastids. They are usually found in the cells of the plant parts where usually sunlight does not reach; for example, root, ovaries and embryo. Their main function is the storage of food.

3. Centriole

A centrosome harbours centrioles closer to the nucleus of a cell. It is composed of two un-overlapped centrioles surrounded by cytoplasm condensed with a mass of protein. They are usually absent in the cells of higher plants and most fungi. At the time of the division of a nucleus in an animal cell, their main function is to organise astral rays.

4. Ribosome

Ribosomes are found in all living cells. It lacks membrane around it, and is the place of the occurrence of protein synthesis. The bondage in polypeptide chains of protein is carried out by ribosome. Moreover, they provide enzymes needed for the cell. Ribosomes are rich in RNA (Ribonucleic acid) which are used in protein synthesis. The ribosome is a complex molecular machine, found within all living cells, that serves as the me of biological protein synthesis. Ribosomes link amino acids together in the order specified by messenger RNA molecules.

5. Golgi body

Golgi body is found within cytoplasm of both plant and animal cells. It is composed of stacks of membrane-bound structure known as cisternae and vesicles. Hydrolysis of different enzymes takes place in its membrane. It involves in the secretion of some hormones and some other different substances in a living cell. It plays some important roles in many metabolic activities. Sometime, golgi body stores protein.

 

6. Endoplasmic reticulum

Ribosomes are studded with the cytoplasmic side of rough endoplasmic reticulum, and so proteins are synthesized in these sites. They play the role of transport of substances. It is found in both plant and animal cell

 

 7. Centrosome

They are found in most animal cells, but they are rarely found in the cells of some lower plants. The centrioles in a centrosome develop astral rays, thus they play a significant role in constructing spindle apparatus.

8. Cell vacuole

Large vacuole is prime feature of a plant cell. Its main function is to contain cell sap. Different types of substances such as inorganic slat, protein, carbohydrate, fat, organic acid, pigment, water etc. are found in a cell vacuole. No vacuole is generally found in any animal cell.

9. Lysosomes

A lysosome is a membrane-bound cell organelle that contains digestive enzymes. Lysosomes are involved with various cell processes. They break down excess or worn-out cell parts. They may be used to destroy invading viruses and bacteria.

10. Nucleus

The nucleus is a membrane bound prominent organelle found in the eukaryotic cells. It is roughly round or spherical in structure. Mature sieve cells and red blood cells lack nucleus. A nucleus houses the hereditary information in it, and controls all the activities of a cell. A well-structured nucleus has the following parts. In a nucleus round shaped structure attached with a chormosome is called nucleolus. This non-membrane bound structure is composed of RNA and proteins. Its main function is to assemble ribosomes in an eukaryotic cell. 

The nucleus contains a thread like coiled structures called chromatin reticulum. Chromatin fibers get super coiled during nuclear division and become more condensed, and then they are called chromosomes. Chromosomes are individually more distinct. They are the units of hereditary, and pass genetic information from generation to generation. Chromosomes contain genes, and thus carry hereditary trait from generation to generation.

 

Euglena is single-celled, and the cell is enclosed in a semi-rigid protein sheath, not a true cell wall but not a simple cell membrane. Structurally, they do not have a cell wall. Instead, they have a thick outer covering, known as a pellicle, that is composed of protein and gives them both strength and flexibility.

Viruses are the smallest known organisms made of two parts; an outer part is protein and the inner part is DNA and RNA. It behaves as both living and non-living organism under different conditions.

In amoeba, the ectoplasm is bounded by a thin membrane known as the plasmalemma

 

UNN PUTME Example

1. The difference between the cell wall of a plant cell and animal cell is that

A. plant cell wall contains silica B. animal cell contains stomata in its membrane C. plant cell is made up of membranes only D. plant cell wall contains cellulose

(Plant contains cellulose cell wall which the animal cell lacks. The cell wall makes the plant cell rigid, 2006/2007, no 1)

 

2. The mitochondrion consists of

A. chemicals that break up complex compounds in the cells into simpler compounds B. rich store of ribonucleic acid C. digestive enzymes and hormones D. protein phosphorus and fats

(The mitochondria which is the power house of the cell contains chemicals that break up complex compounds in the cells into simpler compounds, 2006/2007, no 1)

 

3. In amoeba, the ectoplasm is bounded by a thin membrane known as the

A. plasmasol B. plasmagel C. plasmalemma D. protoplasm

(In amoeba, the ectoplasm is bounded by a thin membrane known as the plasmalemma, 2006/2007, no 2)

 

4. Which of the following parts of a cell is living?

A. Cell wall B. Calcium oxalate C. Food vacuole D. Mitochondria

(D. Mitochondria are membrane-bound cell organelles (mitochondrion, singular) that generate most of the chemical energy needed to power the cell's biochemical reactions, 2010/2011, no 1)

 

5. The sites for energy transfer within cell are known as

A. Golgi apparatus B. Parenchyma C. Mitochondria D. Nucleolus

(C. Mitochondria are known as the powerhouses of the cell, 2010/2011, no 3)

 

6. In mammals, the organ directly on top of the kidney is the

A. Thyroid gland B. Adrenal gland C. Pancreases D. prostate gland

(B. Etymologically, the name adrenal means near (ad) the kidney (renes), 2018/2019, no 12)

 

7. Which of these membranes separate the cell wall from the cytoplasm? 

A. Tonoplast B. Cellulose cell wall C. Middle lamella D. Plasmalemma 

(D. it is a biological membrane that separates the interior of all cells from the outside environment (the extracellular space). The basic function is to protect the cell from its surroundings, 2017/2018, no 13)

 

8. Cells without an organized nucleus are called

A. Heterokaryote B. Eukaryote C. Prokaryote D. Synkaryote

(C. Cells that lack a well-organized nucleus are called prokaryotic cells and we define these cells as cells that do not have membrane-bound organelles. Examples are Bacteria and cyano-bacteria, 2010/2011, no 2)

 

9. In which of the following organisms does a single cell perform all the functions of movement, nutrition, growth, excretion, and photosynthesis

A. paramecium B. euglena C. amoeba D. spirogyra

(B. Euglena is single-celled, and the cell is enclosed in a semi-rigid protein sheath, not a true cell wall but not a simple cell membrane, 2009/2010, no 6)

 

10. A plant cell is different from an animal cell because

A. The nucleus is pushed to the centre B. The nucleus is small C. The cell wall is made of cellulose D. The cytoplasm fills up the entire cell space

(C. The main structural differences between plant and animal cells lie in a few additional structures found in plant cells. These structures include: chloroplasts, the cell wall, and vacuoles, 2010/2011, no 8)

 

11. The spongy mesophyll is a tissue found in

A. Animal cells B. Plant leaves C. Plant roots D. Plant stem

(B. Spongy tissue is a type of tissue found both in plants and animals. In plants, it is part of the mesophyll, where it forms a layer next to the palisade cells in the leaf. The spongy mesophyll's function is to allow for the interchange of gases (CO2) that are needed for photosynthesis)

 

12. Photosynthetic pigments are localized in

A. Chloroplast B. Stroma C. Stomata D. Night blindness

(A. Chloroplasts are green because they contain the pigment chlorophyll, which is vital for photosynthesis)

 

13. The viruses are the smallest known organisms and are divided into two parts; the outer part and the inner part. The outer part is protein and the inner part is

A. nucleus B. vacuole C. particle D. DNA and RNA

(viruses are the smallest known organisms made of two parts; an outer part is protein and the inner part is DNA and RNA. It behaves as both living and non-living organism under different conditions, 2006/2007, no 8)

 

14. Viruses are considered to be living organisms because they 

A. possesses transmittable characters B. move from one place to another C. respond to stimulation D. ingest food materials

(A. Viruses are the smallest known organisms made of two parts; an outer part is protein and the inner part which is composed of genetic material DNA (deoxyribonucleic acid) or RNA (ribonucleic acid)).

 

15. In a cell digestive enzyme mostly occur in

A. ribosome B. lysosome C. mitochondria D. plastids

(B. A lysosome is a membrane-bound cell organelle that contains digestive enzymes. Lysosomes are involved with various cell processes. They break down excess or worn-out cell parts. They may be used to destroy invading viruses and bacteria, 2008/2009, no 3)

 

16. The site of protein synthesis in a cell is

A. golgi apparatus B. ribosomes C. lysosomes D. nucleus

(B. Ribosomes are rich in RNA (Ribonucleic acid) which are used in protein synthesis, 2008/2009, no 6)

 

17. Cellulose is commonly found in

A. animal cell membrane B. plant cell wall C. both plants and animals D. amoeba

(B. Cellulose is present in cell walls of all plants, and some bacteria, and is the most abundant natural polysaccharide on earth, 2012/2013 II, no 4)

 

18. Mitochondria are

A. seat of photosynthesis B. seat of enzyme degradation C. seat of respiration D. seat of photosynthesis

(C. The biochemical processes of the cell are known as cellular respiration, 2012/2013 II, no 9)

 

19. Cellulose is commonly found in

A. animal cell membrane B. plant cell wall C. both plants and animals D. amoeba

(B. Cellulose is present in cell walls of all plants, and some bacteria, and is the most abundant natural polysaccharide on earth 2012/2013, no 4)

 

JAMB Examples

1. Which of the following organisms is multi-cellular?

A. Chlamydomonas B. Spirogyra C. Amoeba D. Euglena

(B. Spirogyra)

 

2. The organ which is sensitive to light in Euglena is the

A. gullet B. flagellum C. chloroplast D. eyespot

(D. eyespot)

 

3. A. golgi apparatus B. ribosome C. lysosomes D. nucleus 

(B. Ribosomes are rich in RNA (Ribonucleic acid) which are used in protein synthesis, 2017/2018, no 11)

 

4. When the adults have reach a certain degree of weakness, the process of binary fission is replaced by conjugation in

A. Paramecium B. Euglena C. Amoeba D. Plasmodium

(A. Paramecium)

 

5. The component of the cell that determines paternity resides in the 

A. centrosome B. ribosome C. nucleus D. mitochondria

(C. nucleus)

 

6. The cytoplasm of the cell is considered a very important component because it 

A. regulates the amount of energy in the cell B. suspends all cell organelles C. is the outermost part of the cell D. is solely responsible for cell division

(B. suspends all cell organelles)
